results.title: Psychosis, Addiction, Chronic Vomiting: As Weed Becomes More Potent, Teens Are Getting Sick
results.abstract: With THC levels close to 100 percent, today’s cannabis products are making some teenagers highly dependent and dangerously ill.

media.caption: Dabbing, a method of inhaling highly concentrated THC, has become increasingly popular among teenagers.
media.copyright: Michelle Groskopf for The New York Times

results.byline: By Rose Courteau, Kate Guadagnino and Miguel Morales
results.title: The 25 Most Significant New York City Novels From the Last 100 Years
results.abstract: Four writers and one bookseller gathered over Zoom to make a list devoted to fiction in which the city is more than mere setting.

media.caption: Gordon Parks’s “Harlem Neighborhood, Harlem, New York” (1952), from the photographer’s “Invisible Man” series.

results.adx_keywords: Snakes;Conservation of Resources;Endangered and Extinct Species;Invasive Species;Environment;Everglades (Fla);Florida
results.title: To Catch a Snake: Largest Python Found in Everglades Signals a Threat
results.abstract: The Burmese python caught by a team of trackers breaks a record and shows the invasive species surviving in Florida’s ecosystem despite efforts to remove those snakes.

results.byline: By Matt Richtel and Andrew Jacobs
results.title: F.D.A. Orders Juul to Stop Selling E-Cigarettes
results.abstract: The agency ruled against the company’s application to stay on the market, a decisive blow to a once-popular vaping brand that appealed to teenagers.

media.caption: In its heyday, Juul occupied 75 percent of the market share and employed 4,000 people.
media.copyright: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Content Type: Service;Boats and Boating;Kayaks;Exercise
results.title: Kayaking: An Outdoor Adventure and a Full-Body Workout
results.abstract: Watercraft sales exploded during the pandemic, and many more garages now have kayaks in them. But do you know how to get the best workout in one?

media.caption: Mathew Skeels demonstrates proper paddling technique. Serious kayak racers generally don’t wear life vests, but recreational paddlers should always do so.
media.copyright: Bryan Bennett for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Mardi Gras;Movies;Restoration and Renovation;History (Academic Subject);New Orleans (La)
results.title: After Decades of Searching, 1898 Film of New Orleans Mardi Gras Is Found
results.abstract: Believed to be the oldest film of New Orleans, the roughly two-minute movie shows both long-held traditions of the parade and rituals that have been changed or forgotten.

media.caption: A scene from a film showing New Orleans Mardi Gras in 1898. The recently discovered film has stunned local historians.

results.title: A Year Later, Some Republicans Second-Guess Boycotting the Jan. 6 Panel
results.abstract: The decision by Representative Kevin McCarthy not to appoint Republicans to the committee has given Democrats the chance to set out an uninterrupted narrative.
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

media.caption: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the Republican minority leader, chose last summer to withdraw all of his nominees to the House committee investigating the riot on Jan. 6, 2021, and its roots.

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Football;McElhenny, Hugh;National Football League;San Francisco 49ers;University of Washington
results.title: Hugh McElhenny, Elusive Hall of Fame Halfback, Is Dead at 93
results.abstract: Known as the King, he was a thrilling figure on the field, twisting and turning as he frustrated defenders on his circuitous romps to the end zone.

media.caption: McElhenny, with the ball, during the 49ers’ 37-7 win over the Green Bay Packers in Milwaukee in 1953. He was “as good an open-field runner as you’ll ever see,” a teammate said.

results.adx_keywords: Dogs;Breeding of Animals;Robberies and Thefts;United States;California
results.title: Never Mind Your Wallet. Armed Robbers Want Your French Bulldog.
results.abstract: The popular breed has become one of the most expensive in the United States. Some owners have started carrying guns for protection.

media.caption: Chris Del Rosario, a partner in a French bulldog breeding business with his brother, Jaymar Del Rosario, rides with a night stick and gun in case anyone dares to steal Cashew.

results.title: The Rise of the 0.5 Selfie

results.title: Saving Historic Songs, and a Jewish Culture in Morocco
results.abstract: For centuries after the expulsion from Spain, Morocco’s Sephardic Jewish women sang of love, loss and identity. Now, they’re almost all gone.

media.copyright: Seif Kousmate for The New York Times

results.title: This Teen Already Broke Some of Usain Bolt’s Records. He’s Getting Faster.
results.abstract: Erriyon Knighton, just out of high school, has already lowered Bolt’s world junior record in the 200 meters. “It’s almost like he’s a pogo stick,” Knighton’s coach said.

results.title: Lisa Joy on ‘Reminiscence,’ ‘Westworld’ and the Lure of Techno-Noir
results.abstract: The writer-director says she is obsessed with time. One way to have more of it is “to create whole new timelines and dimensions.”

media.caption: When she first pitched “Reminiscence,” Lisa Joy said, she was “heavily pregnant” and people would ask, “What the hell is wrong with you? Why are you writing this mysterious, dark, violent, sexy thing?”
media.copyright: Tracy Nguyen for The New York Times

results.title: All of Those Quitters? They’re at Work.

results.adx_keywords: Art;Slavery (Historical);Whitney Biennial;Museums;Black People;Breslin, David (Curator);Cha, Theresa Hak Kyung;Hammons, David;Cannon, Steve;Art Gallery of Ontario;Blumenfeld Development Group;Eastern State Penitentiary;Gathering of the Tribes, A;Queens Museum;Whitney Museum of American Art;Canada;East Village (Manhattan, NY);Trinidad and Tobago
results.title: My Artist Ghost
results.abstract: Nearly 30 years ago, Denyse Thomasos forged a form of abstraction that depicted the unspeakable and unimaginable confinement in slave ships and prisons. Her work had to be seen at the Biennial.

media.caption: Denyse Thomasos, “Displaced Burial/Burial at Gorée” (1993), a mural-size canvas at the Whitney Museum. One of three large paintings whose dense grids of black and white lines evoked structures such as a slave ship, prison and burial site that “left such catastrophic effects on the black psyche,” she wrote.
media.copyright: Matt Grubb for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Palaces and Castles;Historic Buildings and Sites;Restoration and Renovation;Home Repairs and Improvements;Content Type: Personal Profile;Books and Literature;DePree, Hopwood;Middleton (England)
results.title: ‘Downton Shabby’: A Commoner Takes on an English Castle
results.abstract: A Los Angeles actor and producer moved across the pond to restore his crumbling ancestral home. But fixing up a 50,000-square-foot manor isn’t easy.

media.caption: “I first came to see the hall out of curiosity,” said Hopwood DePree, whose initial tour of his ancestral home, in 2013, included the morning room. He decided to stick around to bring the centuries-old property back to its early splendor.
